qas.question: Is a species always the antagonist in a mobbing attack, or can it play roles on both sides?

answers.text: species can be on both ends of a mobbing attack

qas.question: Which bird is an example of being both a predator and defender in mobbing attacks?
Will birds often mob animals that do not pose a threat?
Crows will cooperate with small birds to drive away what predators?
What is an activity usually done by mammalian predators?
What will larger predators do when they see mobbing taking place?
What is one thing hawks do when they see mobbing?
What are hawks often mobbed by when they try to eat their eggs?
What do hawks do when they want to drive away crows?

context: <b4_0>Mobbing<b4_0/> can be an interspecies activity: it is common for birds to respond to mobbing calls of a different species. Many birds will <b5_0>show up<b5_0/> at the sight of mobbing and <b6_0>watch<b6_0/> and call, but not participate. It should also be noted that some <a0_0>species can be on both ends of a mobbing attack<a0_0/>. <a1_0>Crows<a1_0/> are frequently mobbed by <b7_0>smaller songbirds<b7_0/> as they prey on eggs and young from these birds' nests, but these same crows will <b8_0>cooperate with smaller birds<b8_0/> to drive away <a3_0>hawks or larger mammalian predators<a3_0/>. <a2_0>On occasion<a2_0/>, birds will mob animals that pose no threat.
